items.title: Two aspirants who are unlikely to suit the times vie for the Liberal leadership
items.description: Hastie and Taylor each wants to run against Ley. But the two right-wingers can't afford to split the conservative vote on which their tilts would rely.

items.title: As Trump contemplates action, Iranians send the US a message
items.description: Protesters in Iran are begging US President Donald Trump to launch military action to help topple the Islamic regime. But could it happen?

items.title: Singapore without an opposition leader after PM deposes him
items.description: Even for a de facto one-party state, the ruling People's Action Party's decision to dictate who runs Singapore's opposition is remarkable.

items.title: GPS trackers reveal 'likely' illegal e-waste exports from Australia to Asia
items.description: A not-for-profit environmental group put GPS devices in 35 e-waste items and dropped them off at recycling locations in four Australian capital cities. Here's what they found.

items.title: A rate hike on Tuesday will be a 'bitter pill' for middle Australia
items.description: Consumer advocates fear a rate hike when the RBA board meets next week could be the "straw that breaks the camel's back" for borrowers in mortgage stress.

items.title: Trump says Putin agreed not to target Kyiv for one week during cold
items.description: Ukrainians, including residents of the country's capital, are experiencing their toughest winter of the war as Russian attacks target electricity infrastructure.

items.title: Celine Cremer went missing in Tasmania. What could have happened to her?
items.description: Celine Cremer went missing in 2023 from a track in a remote part of Tasmania's north-west. With several recent discoveries in the area, these are the theories of what could have happened.

items.title: EU approves new Iran sanctions, moves to designate IRGC as terrorist group

featured_image.name: EU ministers expected to list IRGC as terror organization ...

items.description:
European Union foreign ministers on Jan. 29 approved a new round of sanctions against Iran over a lethal crackdown on nationwide protests and moved toward listing the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) as a terrorist organisation—an escalation EU officials said would put the force in the same category as groups such as al-Qaeda and ISIS.[1][2]

The measures come amid mounting international pressure on Tehran, as activists and rights groups report thousands killed since demonstrations erupted in late December, while Iranian authorities cite a far lower death toll.[3][4]

items.title: Trump orders Venezuelan airspace reopened for commercial travel

featured_image.name: Trump closes "above and surrounding" Venezuela's airspace ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump said Thursday he has instructed U.S. officials to reopen Venezuelan airspace for commercial travel, a move that could ease flight planning across northern South America and, he suggested, clear the way for Americans to visit Venezuela again.

Trump said he relayed the decision to Venezuela’s acting leader, Delcy Rodríguez, and directed Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy and U.S. military leaders to open “all commercial airspace over Venezuela” by the end of the day. “American citizens will be very shortly able to go to Venezuela, and they’ll be safe there,” Trump said, according to an Associated Press account carried by multiple outlets.[1][2][3]

items.title: EU labels Iran's Revolutionary Guards a terrorist organisation in policy shift
items.description: European Union foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas said "repression cannot go unanswered" as the bloc looked set to categorise the IRGC alongside Islamic State and al Qaeda.

items.title: 'We can do better': Trump's tsar promises 'safer' Minnesota operation
items.description: Tom Homan says he is working on a plan to pull federal agents out of Minnesota as part of a major shift in strategy in the controversial local immigration crackdown.

items.title: Gold, silver, palladium retreat sharply as investors take profits

featured_image.name: Precious metals drop amid profit taking; silver, platinum retreat from ...

items.description:
Gold, palladium, and silver retreated sharply on Thursday as investors locked in profits following a historic rally that pushed precious metals to record highs. The selloff came a day after the Federal Reserve held interest rates steady and as traders reassessed positions after weeks of gains.

Spot gold fell as much as 4% during Thursday's trading to around $5,150 per ounce, pulling back from record highs above $5,500 reached earlier in the week. Palladium tumbled 5% to approximately $1,969 per ounce, while silver dropped more than 5% to around $110 per ounce after briefly touching $120 earlier in the session.[1][2][3]

items.title: Google dismantles massive Chinese cyber network linked to malware
items.description:
Google used a federal court order on Wednesday to dismantle what it describes as one of the largest residential proxy networks in the world, seizing dozens of domains belonging to the Chinese firm IPIDEA and cutting millions of devices from its infrastructure.[1][2][3]

The coordinated action, led by Google's Threat Intelligence Group, targeted a network that cybersecurity researchers say covertly installed malicious software on smartphones, computers, and Android devices worldwide. The operation is expected to disconnect more than nine million Android devices from IPIDEA's network.[4]

items.title: Scientists detect dark matter clump near the Sun for the first time

featured_image.name: Dark matter clumps may have punched through star stream ...

items.description:
New observational evidence is reshaping scientists' understanding of two of the universe's greatest enigmas: the origins of supermassive black holes and the hidden distribution of dark matter in our galaxy. Both breakthroughs rely on innovative techniques to detect objects that cannot be seen directly.

In a paper published January 29 in Physical Review Letters, astronomers led by Sukanya Chakrabarti at the University of Alabama in Huntsville report finding a massive dark matter clump lurking in the galactic neighborhood of the Sun. The suspected subhalo has a mass roughly 10 million times that of the Sun and is located about 3,260 light-years away.[1]

items.title: Study finds microplastics in one third of fish off Pacific islands

featured_image.name: Baby fish are surrounded by and consuming man-made ocean plastic

items.description:
A third of fish living off the coasts of remote Pacific Island nations contain microplastics, according to a study published this week, providing new evidence that plastic pollution has reached even the most isolated marine ecosystems on Earth.

The research, published Wednesday in PLOS One, examined 878 fish from 138 species caught by fishing communities in Fiji, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu. While the overall contamination rate was lower than the global average of 49 percent, researchers found stark disparities between islands—with nearly 75 percent of fish sampled in Fiji containing microplastics, compared to just 5 percent in Vanuatu.[1][2][3]

items.title: UK and China announce trade deals during Starmer's Beijing visit

featured_image.name: Starmer and Xi hail a reset in ties, helped by large AstraZeneca investment

items.description:
British Prime Minister Keir Starmer and Chinese President Xi Jinping announced a series of agreements on Thursday aimed at revitalizing economic ties between their nations, including a $15 billion investment pledge from AstraZeneca and reduced tariffs on Scotch whisky, during the first visit by a UK leader to China in eight years.

The meeting, held at Beijing's Great Hall of the People and lasting approximately 80 minutes, produced what Starmer called "concrete outcomes" that put the bilateral relationship in a "strong place." Xi acknowledged the relationship had experienced "twists and turns" but expressed China's readiness to cultivate a long-term partnership.[1][2][3]

items.title: China, Netherlands, Australia all set renewable energy records in 2025

featured_image.name: China added record wind and solar power in 2025, data shows ...

items.description: Three nations on three continents achieved milestones in clean energy last year, demonstrating the global momentum of the renewable transition even as challenges remain. China installed record amounts of wind and solar capacity, the Netherlands met 57% of its electricity needs from renewables, and Australia's grid crossed the 50% renewable threshold for the first time.

items.title: Scientists propose quantum batteries to power quantum computers

featured_image.name: Quantum batteries could supercharge the future of quantum ...

items.description:
Researchers from Australia and Japan have proposed an approach to powering quantum computers using quantum batteries, a development they say could make future machines faster, more energy efficient, and easier to scale. The theoretical framework, published January 28 in Physical Review X, suggests quantum batteries could quadruple the number of qubits that fit within current cryogenic systems while reducing the infrastructure demands that have long stymied the technology's commercial progress.[1][2]

Quantum computers rely on delicate quantum states to perform calculations far beyond the reach of classical machines, but sustaining those states typically requires room-sized, energy-intensive cryogenic cooling systems and complex room-temperature electronics. These constraints remain among the biggest barriers to scaling quantum computing technology.[3][4]

items.title: Asian researchers report advances in solar panel cooling, perovskite efficiency

featured_image.name: PolyU develops hydrogel coating for solar panels, boosting ...

items.description:
Two research teams in Asia have reported advances aimed at squeezing more electricity from solar hardware in the real world: one by cooling conventional silicon panels at their hottest failure-prone points, the other by pushing perovskite technology closer to scalable, high-efficiency modules.

In Hong Kong, researchers at The Hong Kong Polytechnic University said a hydrogel-based layer can reduce “hot spot” temperatures on panels while raising output, a result they argue could be especially relevant for dense cities with rooftop and building-integrated solar. In South Korea, a team led by Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology (GIST) reported a perovskite mini-module with 22.56% efficiency, addressing a key hurdle in making perovskites perform reliably as device area increases.[1][2][3]

items.title: 'Never happened to me': Sabalenka uses anger to book Aus Open final
items.description: World number one Aryna Sabalenka books her fourth consecutive Australian Open final, defeating Ukraine's Elina Svitolina in straight sets.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
